    Battle against Vancomycin-Resistant Bacteria: Recent Developments in Chemical Strategies

    • Geetika Dhanda
      Geetika Dhanda
      Antimicrobial Research Laboratory, New Chemistry Unit, Jawaharlal Nehru Centre for Advanced Scientific Research, Jakkur, Bengaluru 560064, Karnataka, India
      More by Geetika Dhanda

    SUBJECTS:

    Get e-Alerts

    Abstract

    Vancomycin, a natural glycopeptide antibiotic, was used as the antibiotic of last resort for the treatment of multidrug-resistant Gram-positive bacterial infections. However, almost 30 years after its use, resistance to vancomycin was first reported in 1986 in France. This became a major health concern, and alternative treatment strategies were urgently needed. New classes of molecules, including semisynthetic antibacterial compounds and newer generations of the previously used antibiotics, were developed. Semisynthetic derivatives of vancomycin with enhanced binding affinity, membrane disruption ability, and lipid binding properties have exhibited promising results against both Gram-positive and Gram-negative bacteria. Various successful approaches developed to overcome the acquired resistance in Gram-positive bacteria, intrinsic resistance in Gram-negative bacteria, and other forms of noninherited resistance to vancomycin have been discussed in this Perspective.

    1. Introduction

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    The emergence and spread of antimicrobial resistance (AMR) globally poses a major threat to the management of infectious diseases, resulting in high morbidity and mortality.(1) The World Health Organization’s (WHO) Global Antimicrobial Surveillance System (GLASS) revealed high levels of resistance in a number of serious bacterial infections worldwide. Resistance in bacteria such as Escherichia coli, Klebsiella pneumoniae, Staphylococcus aureus, and Streptococcus pneumoniae, followed by Salmonella spp. are among the most commonly reported.(2) To tackle the rapid emergence of antimicrobial resistance, initiatives were taken by various health organizations and governments, which resulted in the approval of several new antibiotics. Five new classes of antibiotics, lipopeptides (daptomycin), oxazolidinones (linezolid), pleuromutilin (retapamulin), macrocyclic antibiotics (fidaxomicin), and diarylquinoline (bedaquiline), were introduced into the market. The other new antibiotics, which were modifications of the previously existing antibiotics, had limited usefulness due to the pan-class mechanisms of resistance in bacteria. This lack of novel scaffolds from target-based or phenotypic-screening methods had resulted in the withdrawal of pharmaceutical companies from antibiotic research.(3) This further aggravated the problem of AMR. Another aspect of bacterial infection that had been given little attention to earlier is the phenomenon of “noninherited” resistance to antibiotics. In this case, bacteria that are inherently susceptible to antibiotics are often phenotypically resistant to them.(4) The ability of bacteria to cause intracellular infections, form biofilms, and go into a metabolically inactive state contributes to this phenotypic “noninherited” resistance. This noninherited resistance causes an additional burden to AMR and makes treatment more challenging.
    Among all the classes of approved antibiotics, the glycopeptide antibiotics had the highest longevity in the clinic. The advantage of this class of antibiotics was that they worked by binding to the substrate for peptidoglycan synthesis instead of an enzyme, which is prone to mutations, thereby leading to a decreased propensity of resistance. Vancomycin was reserved as an antibiotic of last resort for the treatment of complicated infections caused by multidrug-resistant Gram-positive bacteria which prevented the widespread development of resistance to it. It was not until almost three decades from vancomycin’s introduction in the clinic that resistance to it was observed. The emergence of resistance to this antibiotic raised alarms in the clinic and in the scientific community, calling for immediate measures to curb resistance. According to the list of priority pathogens published by WHO in 2017, vancomycin-resistant Enterococcus faecium and vancomycin-intermediate and resistant S. aureus (VISA and VRSA) come under the high priority category because the number of options for the treatment of vancomycin-resistant bacteria still remain limited.(5)
    This perspective provides an overview of the current treatment options for vancomycin-resistant bacterial infections. Various approaches that have been developed to overcome acquired and noninherited resistance to vancomycin in bacteria have also been highlighted. Additionally, the strategies to increase the spectrum of activity of vancomycin against Gram-negative bacteria have been discussed.

    2. Glycopeptide Progenitors

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Glycopeptide antibiotics constitute an important class of cell-wall biosynthesis inhibitors. They are glycosylated heptapeptides produced by a group of soil actinomycetes and are composed of a tricyclic or tetracyclic nonribosomal peptide core. The glycopeptides are categorized into five different structural subclasses, I–V, based on the amino acid residues for amino acids 1 and 3 in the heptapeptide. Vancomycin, actinoidin A, ristocetin A, teicoplanin, and complestatin are some molecules belonging to these subclasses, respectively.(6) Vancomycin (Figure 1) is the first molecule from this class of antibiotics, which was isolated by Eli Lilly in 1953 and introduced in clinic in 1958.(7) Teicoplanin is another clinically relevant molecule which was first reported in 1978 and approved for clinical use in 1988 in Europe.(8) Vancomycin contains five aromatic amino acids and two aliphatic amino acids, thus belonging to subclass I of glycopeptide antibiotics. Teicoplanin (Figure 1) contains seven aromatic amino acids and a long fatty acid chain linked to the glucosamine sugar, thus being a lipoglycopeptide. Clinically employed teicoplanin is a mixture consisting of teicoplanin A2-1 to A2-5, with A2-2 being the major component. These drugs, especially vancomycin, are mainstays in the treatment of life-threatening infections due to methicillin resistant S. aureus (MRSA).(8) Vancomycin has been recommended intravenously as a treatment for complicated skin structure infections, endocarditis, and bloodstream infections caused by MRSA. Despite the advantages of vancomycin, there were initially many side effects associated with its intravenous administration, including nephrotoxicity, red-man syndrome, and ototoxicity, which have now been resolved due to better purification techniques. It was associated with relatively poor pharmacokinetic (half-life = 4–11 h) and tissue penetrating properties as compared to other glycopeptide antibiotics. Sometimes, teicoplanin is preferred over vancomycin due to its better potency against various clinical isolates belonging to Enterococcus, Staphylococcus, and Streptococcus genera and its better tolerability.(8,9) It has better pharmacokinetic properties (half-life = 30 h) and may be administered intravenously or intramuscularly.

    3. Mechanism of Action

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    The glycopeptide antibiotics inhibit cell-wall biosynthesis by binding to the d-Ala–d-Ala moiety of the peptidoglycan precursors (lipid II and immature peptidoglycan), thus averting transglycosylation and transpeptidation in the later extracytoplasmic stages of cell wall biosynthesis (Figure 2). This complex of glycopeptide antibiotics with the d-Ala–d-Ala terminus is stabilized via five hydrogen bonds, hydrophobic forces, and van der Waals forces. Vancomycin is known to form back to back dimers in solution, which results in an improved binding affinity to the substrate. The binding constant of vancomycin with the d-Ala–d-Ala terminus is 4.4 × 105 M–1.(10) However, unlike vancomycin, teicoplanin does not form dimers. Additional membrane-anchoring properties are imparted by the lipophilic moiety of teicoplanin which improves association and thus binding affinity with the substrate. This mechanism of action makes the glycopeptide antibiotics less susceptible to resistance as compared to the enzyme-targeting antibiotics, which are easily rendered ineffective due to genetic alterations. It was due to this unique mechanism of action that vancomycin enjoyed decades of resistance-free use.

    4. Resistance Development

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    The first instance of vancomycin resistance occurred in Enterococcus faecium in France in 1986.(11) In the USA, the rise of vancomycin-resistant Enterococci (VRE), a prolific colonizer, gained pace due to the ever-increasing use of vancomycin in hospital settings. In Europe, it happened in communities, probably due to overuse of avoparcin (another glycopeptide antibiotic, used as a growth promoter in livestock).(12) Later, in 1996, S. aureus with decreased susceptibility to vancomycin was first isolated from an infant patient admitted in a hospital in Japan.(13) This vancomycin intermediate S. aureus (VISA) strain (Mu50) has been serving as a typical VISA strain with vancomycin minimum inhibitory concentration (MIC) of 8 μg mL–1 since isolation.
    The first report of high vancomycin resistance in S. aureus, which is known as vancomycin resistant S. aureus (VRSA), came in 2002 as a clinical isolate with MIC > 32 μg mL–1 accompanied by VRE (vanA positive, vancomycin resistance gene cluster), which was identified from a catheter-related infection of a hospitalized patient in USA.(14) A strain of S. aureus is considered to be a hetero-VISA (hVISA) strain if it contains subpopulations of cells that grow on the <4 μg mL–1 vancomycin-containing BHI agar plate, whereas for VISA and VRSA, the MICs are 4–8 and 16 μg mL–1 in broth dilution, respectively.(15) The following section covers the details of the mechanisms of resistance to vancomycin, including the intrinsic resistance seen in Gram-negative bacteria.

    4.1. Acquired Resistance

    Acquired resistance to vancomycin is due to production of peptidoglycan precursors ending with d-Ala–d-Lac and d-Ala–d-Ser instead of d-Ala–d-Ala, which bind to vancomycin with highly diminished affinity (Figure 3). To date, 11 gene clusters that confer resistance to vancomycin in enterococci have been identified. The vanA, vanB, vanD, vanF, vanI, and vanM encode d-Ala–d-Lac, whereas clusters vanC, vanE, vanG, vanL, and vanN are linked to d-Ala–d-Ser resistance. The vanA and vanB gene clusters are the most commonly encountered genes.(16,17) The production of these peptidoglycan precursors leads to a 1000-fold loss in binding affinity of vancomycin to the target peptide with association constant of the order of 102 M–1.(10)
    The vanA and vanB gene clusters comprise variants of three resistance genes namely vanH, vanX, and vanA and homologues which are essential for d-Ala–d-Lac mediated resistance.(18) The presence of vancomycin, teicoplanin, or other compounds that cause perturbation of cell wall precursors causes the VanS protein (a membrane-associated sensor kinase) to autophosphorylate. This, in turn induces phosphorylation of the VanR protein, a cytoplasmic response regulator and transcriptional activator. The VanR increases the expression of the vanR and vanS genes, binds to the vanHAX core, and regulates the expression of the resistance genes of the vanA and vanB clusters.(17,19) The vanH genes encode a d-lactate dehydrogenase that reduces pyruvate into d-Lac and vanX encodes a d,d-dipeptidase that hydrolyzes d-Ala–d-Ala. VanA and its homologues encode a ligase that synthesizes d-Ala–d-Lac.(20) Additionally, vanY, encoding for a d,d-carboxypeptidase, is also present in the vanA and vanB clusters. It cleaves the d-Ala at the C-terminus of late membrane-bound peptidoglycan precursors.(21) In vanA and vanB clusters, another gene vanZ encodes for a protein that confers low-level teicoplanin resistance.(22) In recent years, vancomycin-resistant bacteria have evolved to produce a single VanXY enzyme which is able to mediate both the activities of d,d-dipeptidase and d,d-pentapeptidase.(23,24)
    Vancomycin-resistance in VISA results from the thickening of the bacterial cell wall. In most cases, the relevant mutated genes (walkR system, yvqF/vraSR system) appear to be directly or indirectly involved with the biosynthesis or metabolism of the two-component sensory regulatory systems that control transcription of genes in cell wall biosynthesis.(25−28) However, mutations in the RNA polymerase gene rpoB were also detected in VISA isolates.(29) Apart from these genes, genes encoding β-lactamase have been shown to take part in the VISA phenotype.(30,31) VISA isolates share properties such as excess of cell wall material, aberrant separation of daughter cells after cell division, and diminished rates of autolysis.(32−38) The molecular mechanisms behind these altered phenomena still remain to be explained. VISA isolates are notable for the abnormally high quantities of synthesized peptidoglycan that result in irregularly shaped and thickened cell walls (Figure 3). A recent study on VISA strains (Mu50 lineage) suggested that activated arginine catabolism under regulation of two-component regulatory systems, VraSR and GraRS, is responsible for providing adenosine triphosphate (ATP) molecules and ammonia to compensate for increased cell wall biosynthesis in VISA.(39) Further investigations are necessary to attribute this phenomenon globally to VISA strains of different lineages.
    Additionally, in the thickened cell wall, decreased cross-linking of peptidoglycan strands were detected, which results in an increase of non-cross-linked d-alanyl–d-alanine side chains.(40,41) Sieradzki et al. had shown that when vancomycin is added to the culture medium of VISA/VRSA laboratory mutant strains, it completely disappears. The bound vancomycin to d-Ala–d-Ala acts as a barrier to rest of the free vancomycin molecules to reach further inside.(42,43)
    Genotypic analysis of VRSA indicated that its resistance genes were acquired from VRE.(44) In some strains of VRSA, resistance was found to be due to both cell wall thickening as well as modified pentapeptide termini (Figure 3).(33)

    4.2. Intrinsic Resistance in Gram-Negative Bacteria

    Gram-negative bacteria possess an additional outer membrane, which acts as a barrier for entry of hydrophilic molecules like the glycopeptides. Further, their high molecular weight and size prevents their permeation through porins in the outer membrane to reach the cell wall region. This results in the intrinsic resistance of Gram-negative bacteria to glycopeptides.

    5. Current Therapeutics in the Clinic to Treat Vancomycin-Resistant Infections

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Currently, linezolid (Zyvox) and combination of quinupristin and dalfopristin (Synercid) (Figure 4) are the antibiotics which have been approved for the treatment of infections caused by vancomycin-resistant E. faecium.(45,46) They exhibit in vitro activity against vancomycin-resistant E. faecalis as well and have been employed for clinical studies.(45) Linezolid is an oxazolidinone antibiotic which was approved by the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) of the United States in 2000. It inhibits the formation of the initiation complex formed between the mRNA, N-formylmethionine tRNA (fMet-tRNA), and the 30S ribosomal subunit, thus inhibiting protein synthesis in bacteria. It has close to 100% bioavailability with slight toxicity in the form of myelosuppression, serotonin syndrome, neuropathy, and lactic acidosis.(47) Linezolid has been approved in the US for vancomycin-resistant E. faecium infections, including bacteremia, nosocomial and community-associated pneumonia (CAP) caused by methicillin-susceptible and resistant S. aureus (MSSA and MRSA), or multidrug-resistant Streptococcus pneumoniae and complicated and uncomplicated skin and skin structure infections (SSSi).(48) Quinupristin and dalfopristin belong to the streptogramin class of antibiotics and were approved as a combination therapy by the FDA in 1998. They work by inhibition of bacterial protein synthesis in the elongation phase. The combination therapy is provided as a 30:70 ratio of quinupristin (pristinamycin I A, a group B streptogramin) and dalfopristin (pristinamycin II A, a group A streptogramin). This combination received approval for use in adults for the treatment of infections caused by vancomycin-resistant E. faecium and for the treatment of complicated skin and skin structure infections (cSSSi) caused by MSSA or Streptococcus pyogenes. This combination is rarely employed for treatment due to its high toxicity.
    In addition to these antibiotics, daptomycin (Cubicin), tedizolid (Silvextro), and tigecycline (Tygacil) have shown promising in vitro activity and good clinical results against vancomycin-resistant bacteria, although they have not been approved for use against these infections.(45) They have been employed for the treatment of vancomycin-resistant infections off-label. Reduced susceptibility of vancomycin-resistant strains to linezolid and daptomycin was reported within a few years of their introduction.(49,50) Considering the limited number of options for the treatment of infections caused by vancomycin-resistant bacteria, there is an urgent need for new antibacterial agents to fill in the clinical void.

    6. Clinically Approved Semisynthetic Glycopeptides

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    The next generation glycopeptides are semisynthetic derivatives of the naturally occurring glycopeptides, which show enhanced antibacterial activity against vancomycin-sensitive as well as vancomycin-resistant strains. Telavancin (Vibativ), dalbavancin (Dalvance), and oritavancin (Orbactiv) are the clinically approved semisynthetic glycopeptides (Figure 5). These are lipoglycopeptides which have lipophilic moieties linked to the core structure, just like teicoplanin. The long lipophilic moieties help with membrane-anchoring, which enhances binding affinity to the substrate, thus making them more potent than the naturally occurring glycopeptides. By virtue of their lipophilic character, they demonstrate better pharmacodynamic and pharmacokinetic properties.(7,8,51) Telavancin consists of a (phosphomethyl) aminomethyl moiety substituted at the para position of the aromatic ring of the dihydroxyphenylglycine residue, to increase solubility and a decylaminoethyl moiety conjugated to the vancosamine sugar of vancomycin to impart membrane-anchoring function. It has enhanced bactericidal properties due to its membrane-disruptive mechanism of action and improved tissue distribution due to the (phosphomethyl) aminomethyl moiety with a terminal half-life of about 8 h.(52,53) In 2009, it was approved by the FDA for the treatment of cSSSi and, later, in 2013, for treatment of hospital-acquired and ventilator-associated pneumonia caused by S. aureus. Dalbavancin is a semisynthetic variant of the teicoplanin family member, A40926. It has a terminally branched dodecyl chain, linked via an amide bond to the glucosamine of the parent drug. This mimics the fatty acyl moiety of teicoplanin which is important to impart membrane anchoring properties. It is also modified through the amidation of the C-terminus carboxyl with an N,N-dimethylpropylamine group. It shows an MIC of 0.1 μg mL–1 against VRE (VanB phenotype).(54) Dalbavancin was approved by the FDA in 2014 for the treatment of acute skin and skin-structure infections caused by MSSA and MRSA, vancomycin susceptible E. faecalis, and Streptococci. Its half-life ranges from 149 to 250 h.(51) Oritavancin is the N-aryl derivative of the natural product chloroeromomycin. Here, the chlorophenyl-benzyl group is attached to the parent glycopeptide by imine bond formation and subsequent reduction between the corresponding aldehyde and epivancosamine of chloroeremomycin. The chlorophenyl-benzyl group serves to be a good replacement for the fatty acyl groups present in the natural glycopeptides and confers good activity against VRE. In addition to the d-Ala–d-Ala terminus, oritavancin binds to the pentaglycyl bridging segment of the peptidoglycan of Enterococci, thus significantly inhibiting transpeptidation. Oritavancin exhibits MICs of <1 μg mL–1 against MRSA and vancomycin-resistant pathogens.(55) It was approved by the FDA in 2014 for the treatment of infections caused by MSSA, MRSA, vancomycin-susceptible E. faecalis, and Streptococci.(51) Its half-life is 393 h.(56) Although these semisynthetic glycopeptides have been approved by the FDA, they are yet to be approved for the treatment of vancomycin-resistant infections.

    7. Recent Developments to Tackle Acquired Resistance

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    With growing resistance to vancomycin manifested in the form of VRE, VISA, and VRSA, there is an urgent need to develop novel antibiotics. Resistance to vancomycin can be tackled by either developing semisynthetic derivatives of the natural glycopeptide antibiotics to increase their potency or synthesizing and isolating novel antibacterial agents. Semisynthetic approaches involve structural modifications that could lead to an additional mechanism of action, which could result in improved efficacy and low propensity of resistance development. Antibacterial compounds with novel mechanisms of action are advantageous as they are not subject to cross-resistance with glycopeptides. The subsequent sections focus on the recent developments to combat vancomycin resistance through the semisynthesis and synthesis of novel vancomycin type antibiotics. Further, a brief account of other antibacterial agents which have shown activity against vancomycin-resistant bacteria has been given. Developments to tackle Gram-negative pathogens, remedy intracellular infections, and biofilm formation have also been focused upon.

    7.1. Modifications of Vancomycin

    Vancomycin has many sites whose modification would not compromise its ability to bind to the target. This allows tailoring of the basic structure to incorporate moieties that enhance binding affinity or anchor and disrupt the membrane, thereby overcoming resistance. Thus, various functionalities like amino, hydroxyl, carboxyl, and the chloro substituents of the triaryl biether backbone have been exploited for modifications.(57) In this section, we have focused on the strategies that have proved to be successful in tackling vancomycin-resistant bacteria (Table 1).
    Table 1. Strategies to Overcome Acquired Resistance of Gram-Positive Bacteria to Vancomycin
    strategy chemical modificationsactivity (MIC)refs
    (A) increasing binding affinity to the target peptide→core modifications•[Ψ[CH2NH]Tpg4] vancomycinVRE-VanA (31 μg mL–1)(61)
      •[Ψ[C(═NH)NH]Tpg4] vancomycin (2a)VRE-VanA (0.5 μg mL–1)(62)
      •CBP derivative of [Ψ[C(═NH)NH]Tpg4] vancomycin (2b)VRE-VanA (0.005 μg mL–1)(62)
      •[Ψ[C(═S)NH]Tpg4] vancomycin>32 μg mL–1 
      •CBP derivative of [Ψ[C(═S)NH]Tpg4] vancomycin (2c)VRE-VanB (2 μg mL–1)(62)
     →peripheral modifications•cyclic and acyclic sugars conjugated with the C-terminus of vancomycin, e.g., lactobionic acid–vancomycin conjugate (3)VRE-VanA (36 μM)(65)
      •lipophilic lactobionic acid–vancomycin conjugate for membrane-anchoring properties, e.g., lactobionic acid–vancomycin conjugate with decyl moiety at the vancosamine (4)VRE-VanA (0.7 μM)(65)
     →homomeric multivalent analogues•Bis (vancomycin) carboxamides (5a–5c)VRE-VanA (11 μM)(66)
      •trivalent vancomycin derivatives using amide coupling at C-terminus (6) (67)
      •multivalent vancomycin derivatives using ROMP (7)VRE-VanB (2 μg mL–1)(68)
      •dimers by bridging the saccharide domains of vancomycin in a back-to-back fashion using disulfide and olefin tether (8)VRE (1–2 μg mL–1) VISA (1 μg mL–1)(69)
      •[Pt(en)2(vancomycin)2]2+ (to impart structural rigidity and minimize loss in conformational entropy) (9)VRE-VanA (0.8 μg mL–1) VRE-VanB (0.28 μg mL–1) VRE-VanC (0.03 μg mL–1)(73)
      •vancomycin aglycon dimer containing two permanent positive charges in the linker (10)VRE-VanA (48 μM) VISA (0.1 μM)(74)
      •lipophilic vancomycin aglycon dimer with an octyl chain (for membrane-anchoring properties) (11)VRE-VanA (2.5 μM) VISA (0.6 μM)(74)
      •vancomycin homodimers and heterodimers by linking azide-functionalized C-terminus vancomycin derivatives with alkyne-functionalized C-terminus vancomycin derivatives (12a–12c)VRE-VanB (0.8 μg mL–1)(75)
         
    (B) incorporation of membrane-disruptive properties→lipidation•methyl ether derivatives of vancomycin aglycon by completely or partially methylating the aryl hydroxyl groups, e.g., tetramethyl ether analogue of vancomycin aglycon, also esterified at the C-terminus (13)VRE-VanB (1.6 μg mL–1)(76)
      •replacement of chloro groups of vancomycin with carbon substituents using Suzuki–Miyaura cross-coupling, e.g., vancomycin derivative by replacement of chloro group of residue-2 with styryl group (14)VRE-VanB (2 μg mL–1)(77)
      •positional isomers of lipidated/acylated vancomycin at hydroxyl groups prepared using π (methyl) histidine (Pmh)-based catalysts (15)VRE-VanB (0.25–1 μg mL–1) VRE-VanS (0.25–0.5 μg mL–1) VRE-VanA (16 μg mL–1)(78)
      •lipophilic vancomycin–sugar conjugates with lipophilic substitutions at the vancosamine and sugar moieties on the phenyl ring of the seventh amino acid (16)VRE-VanA (1–2 μg mL−1) VRE-VanB (≤0.06 μg mL−1) VISA (0.12 μg mL−1)(79)
     →conjugation of lipophilic moieties with a permanent positive charge•attachment of lipophilic quaternary ammonium groups with alkyl chains (octyl and tetradecyl-best derivatives) (17a, 17b)VRE-VanA (0.7 μM) VISA (0.36 μM)(81,82)
      •lipophilic vancomycin–sugar conjugates (membrane-disruptive properties and enhanced binding affinity) (17c)VRE-VanA (0.09 μM) VISA (0.10 μM)(83)
     →modifications in the [Ψ[CH2NH]Tpg4 vancomycin to confer multiple synergistic mechanisms of actionattachment of CBP group and peripheral quaternary ammonium salt to [Ψ[CH2NH]Tpg4] (18)VRE-VanA (0.01–0.005 μg mL–1)(63)
     →vancomycin–peptide conjugatesconjugation of vancomycin with moieties consisting of electrostatic effector peptide sequence (EEPS) and a hydrophobic membrane-insertive element (MIE) (19a–19d)VRE-VanA (0.125 μg mL–1) VRSA (0.05 μg mL–1) VISA (0.03 μg mL–1)(84)
         
    (C) conjugation of groups to enhance interactions with other components of the bacterial membrane and cell wall→targeting the pyrophosphate of the C55–lipid (bactoprenol)conjugation of dipicolyl-1,6-hexadiamine (Dipi) to the C-terminus of vancomycin (20)VRE-VanB (1.5 μM) VISA (1 μM) VRE-VanA (2 μM)(85)
     →targeting saccharides of the cell walltethering benzoxaborole group to vancomycin (21)VISA (1–2 μM)(86)

    7.1.1. Increasing Binding Affinity to the Target Peptides

    Approaches to enhance the binding affinity of vancomycin to the target peptide (d-Ala–d-Ala and d-Ala–d-Lac) include modifications to the peptide backbone and periphery to increase hydrogen-bonding interactions and the development of homomeric multivalent analogues of the drug. All approaches exhibited promising results.
    7.1.1.1. Modifications of the Peptide Core
    Modifications at different amino-acid residues of vancomycin have been made in order to make up for the lost binding affinity. These include modifications of residue-1 (l-leucine), residue-3 (l-aspargine), and residue-4 (dihydroxyphenylglycine), to name a few.(58,59) These strategies rely on total synthesis of the compounds rather than small manipulations in the parent compound, thus presenting significant synthetic challenges.
    In the past, it had been established that lone pair–lone pair repulsions between vancomycin and the mutated target peptide, d-Ala–d-Lac (100-fold contribution), and loss in H-bonding between vancomycin and the mutated target peptide (10-fold contribution) are both responsible for the lost binding affinity. This indicated that the designs that emphasize on eliminating the destabilizing lone pair repulsion between the vancomycin residue-4 carbonyl and the d-Ala–d-Lac ester oxygen would significantly increase the binding affinity.(60) Therefore, vancomycin analogues with residue-4 pocket modifications were developed by Boger and co-workers thereafter (Figure 6). Initially, an analogue, [Ψ[CH2NH]Tpg4] vancomycin aglycon (1a, Figure 6) containing a methylene group instead of the residue-4 amide carbonyl was developed.(61) Although this design relied on the strength of only four hydrogen bonds, it retained activity against the vancomycin-sensitive strains. This analogue demonstrated a 40-fold increase in affinity for d-Ala–d-Lac and a 35-fold reduction in affinity for d-Ala–d-Ala as compared to vancomycin.(61)
    Subsequently, the group engineered a reverse hydrogen bonding group by introducing an amidine group in place of the carbonyl at residue-4 of vancomycin.(62) This [Ψ[C(═NH)NH]Tpg4] vancomycin aglycon (1b) binds to both d-Ala–d-Ala and the mutated ligand d-Ala–d-Lac with high affinity.(62) A thioamide analogue of the vancomycin aglycon was also synthesized (1c, Figure 6). To incorporate both enhanced binding affinity and sufficient hydrophobicity in the same molecule, Boger’s group developed the (4-chlorobiphenyl) methyl (CBP) derivative of 2a (2b).(62) Furthermore, the corresponding CBP derivative of the thioamide analogue, [Ψ[C(═S)NH]Tpg4] vancomycin was also prepared (2c).(62) The binding constant of 1c was determined which clearly suggested an alternative mechanism of action conferred by the CBP group in 2c. The antibacterial efficacies of the above-mentioned vancomycin analogues are given in Figure 6. The results indicate a synergistic effect between the pocket and peripheral modifications in vancomycin. The CBP group inhibits transglycosylation and thus cell wall biosynthesis, independent of d-Ala–d-Ala/d-Ala–d-Lac binding.(63)
    7.1.1.2. Increasing the Scope of H-Bonding with the Pentapeptide by Peripheral Modifications
    A water molecule bridges the H-bonding interaction between the C-terminus of vancomycin and the peptide nitrogen atom of the ligand.(64) It was thus conjectured that modification of the C-terminus with moieties that can form direct hydrogen bonds with the N atom of the target peptide, also present in the mutated pentapeptide terminus, could stabilize the vancomycin–ligand complex. This would further enhance the binding affinity. In a strategy developed in our group, cyclic, acyclic, and cyclic–acyclic sugars were conjugated to the C-terminus of vancomycin.(65) The sugars provide additional H-bond interactions and thus enhance the binding affinity to the mutated target peptide while retaining affinity with the sensitive terminus. Among the synthesized compounds, the derivatives with lactobionic acid and gluconic acid conjugated to the carboxylic acid group of vancomycin exhibited highest affinity to the mutated pentapeptide terminus. The optimized compound, lactobionic acid-vancomycin conjugate (3, Figure 7) showed 170-fold higher affinity for the model peptide N,N-diacetyl-Lys–d-Ala–d-Lac than vancomycin.(65)
    To further improve the activity, alkyl chains were appended to the amino group of vancosamine in the optimized vancomycin–lactobionic acid conjugate to yield the lipophilic sugar–vancomycin conjugates.(65) This was expected to confer additional membrane-anchoring properties as seen in teicoplanin and the second-generation glycopeptides. The derivative with a decyl chain was selected as the optimized compound (4). MICs for this compound can be referred to in Figure 7. The 1000-fold increase in activity of the lipophilic vancomycin–sugar conjugate highlights the importance of synergism shown by additional hydrogen bonding to the substrate and membrane-anchoring properties. This strategy paves a way for a rational approach in the development of novel glycopeptide antibiotics.
    7.1.1.3. Development of Homomeric Multivalent Analogues
    Except for teicoplanin, glycopeptide antibiotics are known to form dimers through hydrogen bonding and hydrophobic interactions.(6) Vancomycin dimerizes through four amide–amide hydrogen bonds. This noncovalent dimerization is co-operative with ligand binding and results in stronger binding than the monomers. The self-association of vancomycin in solution is weak (Kdim = 700 M–1), suggesting that noncovalent self-association might not play a significant role in its biological action.(66) Employing this information to increase the binding affinity of vancomycin to the mutated target peptide, scientists developed various multivalent homomeric analogues to increase the binding affinity. This strategy was one of the first in addressing the problem of vancomycin resistance seen in bacteria. The various designs have been explained in Table 1 and illustrated in Figure 8.(66−75)

    7.1.2. Incorporation of Membrane-Disruptive Properties

    Teicoplanin and second-generation glycopeptides highlighted the importance of membrane-anchoring properties served by hydrophobic chains. In the previous section, we have already seen glimpses of lipophilic vancomycin–sugar conjugates and lipophilic vancomycin dimers to impart membrane-anchoring properties. Taking a cue from these, numerous lipo-vancomycin derivatives were developed by various groups, although their membrane-disruptive properties were not investigated (13–16, Figure 9).(76−79) Reports on the introduction of lipophilic moieties to glycopeptides are well documented in literature.(58,80) Molecules containing lipophilic moieties with a permanent positive charge have been known to show antibacterial properties through enhanced interactions with the negatively charged bacterial membrane. Incorporating this idea into glycopeptide antibiotics, membrane-disrupting lipophilic cationic vancomycin derivatives were developed (17, Figure 9).(81−83) This strategy was coupled with other strategies that enhance binding affinity for the target peptide to develop highly potent vancomycin derivatives by Boger’s group and Haldar’s group (17c, Figure 9; 18, Figure 10). Boger’s group recently incorporated two peripheral modifications into the previously synthesized [Ψ[CH2NH]Tpg4] vancomycin (18).(63) The two peripheral modifications involved the introduction of a CBP group to the pendant disaccharide and a membrane-active component to the C-terminus through amidation reaction. The first modification could inhibit transglycosylation and thus cell wall biosynthesis more effectively. The second modification conferred membrane-active properties to the glycopeptide. Both modifications were coupled in [Ψ[CH2NH]Tpg4] vancomycin to yield the final compound with a CBP group and a peripheral quaternary ammonium salt, which showed activity against VRE-Van A (18). The compound was >10-fold more potent than the CBP derivative alone, >1000-fold more potent than the [Ψ[CH2NH]Tpg4] vancomycin pocket analogue, and a striking >10000-fold more potent than vancomycin itself. Recently, in another design, vancapticins were developed by Blaskovich et al. wherein vancomycin was conjugated with moieties that incorporate membrane-disruptive properties. The membrane-interactive moiety consisted of an electrostatic effector peptide sequence (EEPS) and a hydrophobic membrane-insertive element (MIE) (19, Figure 10).(84) The details of the various derivatives which exhibited activity against vancomycin-resistant strains using this strategy have been covered in Table 1, Figure 9, and Figure 10.

    7.1.3. Conjugation of Groups to Enhance Interactions with Other Components of the Bacterial Membrane and Cell Wall

    Various other components of the bacterial cell membrane can be targeted to inhibit the process of cell-wall biosynthesis. The phosphate group of the C55-lipid (bactoprenol) in the bacterial membrane helps in the transport of the precursor N-acetylglucosamine-N-acetylmuramic acid pentapeptide (GlcNAc-MurNAc pp) from the cytoplasm to the exterior of the cell membrane to further the formation of the peptidoglycan chain. Because the target for vancomycin lies in the vicinity of the membrane, conjugating moieties that can bind to the other components of the membrane is an interesting strategy to enhance activity. In an effort to restore the activity of vancomycin in resistant strains, a Zn2+ binding ligand, dipicolyl-1,6-hexadiamine (Dipi) was conjugated to the C-terminus of vancomycin (Dipi-van) in our lab (20, Figure 11A).(85) The idea was that the dipicolyl amine moiety would capture zinc ions (Zn2+), which could be released from apoptotic cells at the site of bacterial infection with high selectivity. The Dipi-van-Zn2+ could then complex with the pyrophosphate of the cell membrane lipids (Figure 11B). The enhanced inhibition of cell-wall biosynthesis was confirmed by the intracellular accumulation of the precursor, UDP-N-acetylmuramyl-pentadepsipeptide (UDPMurNAc-pp) (Figure 11C). Dipi-van exhibited a 375-fold and 160-fold increase in activity against VREm (VanA phenotype, E. faecium) and VREs (VanB phenotype, E. faecalis) as compared to vancomycin, respectively (Figure 11A). Further, this compound reduced the bacterial burden in mice in VRE kidney infection (5 log CFU g−1 reduction). It did not show any increase in MIC when bacteria were subjected to serial passages of the compound indicating no susceptibility to resistance development.
    Furthermore, components of the cell wall like the saccharides can also be targeted to enhance the activity of the drug. In another approach to enhance activity by targeting other components of the cell wall, Zhang et al. tethered a benzoxaborole group to the C-terminus of vancomycin, eremomycin, and teicoplanin aglycons, as well as to vancomycin, or to the N-terminus of vancomycin and teicoplanin aglycon, or to the amine of vancosamine and N-terminus of vancomycin.(86) The rationale behind this was that the benzoxaborole group would form additional interactions with the 1,2- and 1,3-diols of saccharides coating the cell surface and therefore enhance the efficacy of the drugs (21, Figure 12).

    7.2. Glycopeptide Hybrids with Other Antibacterials

    Antibiotic hybrids provide an interesting approach toward tackling resistance development as they combine the mechanisms of action of different antibiotics. Such hybrids could delay resistance development as genetic alterations in two biological targets are less feasible. In one report, vancomycin–nisin conjugates were developed by linking the C-terminus or N-terminus of vancomycin to the C-terminus of nisin through variable linkers using click chemistry. Nisin is an antimicrobial peptide whose N-terminus is known to bind to the pyrophosphate of lipid II. It was conjectured that through the combination of both moieties in a single molecule, simultaneous lipid II binding of the two parts could lead to increased affinity through bivalency or chelate effect and reinstate the activity of vancomycin to the resistant strains. One of the developed conjugates showed a 40-fold increase in activity against VRE (22, Figure 12).(87) Similarly, it was speculated that conjugating a glycopeptide with a β-lactam would result in enhanced antibacterial activity due to the combined mode of action of β-lactams and glycopeptides for cell wall biosynthesis inhibition. With this concept, Theravance Biopharma, Inc., developed vancomycin–cephalosporin hybrids. Out of these, TD-1607 is currently in phase II clinical trials.(88,89) Another such hybrid, Cefilavancin (TD-1792) was reported to enter phase III clinical trials in 2015 but no development has been reported thereafter. These derivatives exhibited enhanced bactericidal activity but were not effective against vancomycin-resistant strains.

    8. Tackling Infections Caused by Gram-Negative Bacteria

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Gram-negative bacteria are intrinsically resistant to vancomycin due to the presence of an additional outer membrane composed of lipopolysaccharide. According to the list of priority pathogens published by the WHO in 2017, all the highly critical pathogens are Gram-negative bacteria. Given the dearth of antibiotics to treat infections caused by Gram-negative bacteria, new strategies have to be devised. Various strategies have been employed to extend the spectrum of activity of vancomycin to treat such infections (Table 2). Such strategies are welcome as they would provide a new approach to tackle Gram-negative bacteria. This section gives an overview of these strategies.
    Table 2. Strategies To Tackle Intrinsic Resistance of Gram-Negative Bacteria to Vancomycin
    strategyexamplesactivityrefs
    (A) incorporation of membrane-active propertiescationic lipophilic derivative of vancomycin (17b)A. baumannii-R4942 (MIC = 3 μM) E. cloacae: NDM-1 (MIC = 12.5 μM) P. aeruginosa-R590 (MIC = 6.1 μM)(90)
         
    (B) adjuvant therapy•employment of silver (Ag+) as an adjuvant with vancomycin90% survival of mice in an acute mouse peritonitis E. coli infection model(91)
     •polymyxin–tobramycin hybrids as adjuvant with vancomycinP. aeruginosa (MIC of vancomycin reduced to 0.5 μg mL–1)(92)
     •colistin as an adjuvant with teicoplaninA. baumannii (MIC of teicoplanin ≤2 μg mL–1)(94)
     •colistin as an adjuvant with telavancinMIC of telavancin <1 μg mL–1 against clinical isolates(95)
     •nitrofurantoin as an adjuvant with vancomycinE. coli (MIC of vancomycin = 12.5 μg mL–1)(96)
     •trimethoprim as an adjuvant with vancomycinE. coli (MIC of vancomycin = 6.25 μg mL–1)(96)
         
    (C) vancomycin derivative as metallo-β-lactamase inhibitorZn2+ binding Dipi-van as a metallo-β-lactamase inhibitor used in combination with Meropenem (Figure13A)MIC of Meropenem reduced to 3.15 μg mL–1 against NDM-1 producing Gram-negative pathogens(97)
         
    (D) other approaches•loading vancomycin into fusogenic liposomes composed of phospholipid–cholesterol hemisuccinate mixtureE. coli and A. baumannii (MIC = 6 μg mL–1)(98)
     •conjugation of vancomycin with gold nanoparticlesE. coli (8 μg mL–1)(99)

    8.1. Membrane-Active Semisynthetic Derivatives of Vancomycin

    The cationic lipophilic analogue of vancomycin (17b, Figure 9) displayed remarkable activity against Gram-negative pathogens, including carbapenem-resistant clinical isolates with MICs ranging from 1.2 to 6.1 μM.(90) It could permeabilize and depolarize the outer and inner cell membranes of E. coli, proving that the compounds compromised the cell membrane integrity. Compound 17b did not induce resistance in A. baumannii, although the currently used antibiotic, colistin showed an increase in MIC from the fifth passage of antibiotic exposure itself. It exhibited good in vivo antibacterial activity against A. baumannii in mouse thigh infection model (3 log CFU g–1 reduction in bacterial load). Thus, conjugation of cationic lipophilic moieties with a permanent positive charge was proved to be effective even in clinically relevant Gram-negative pathogens due to an additional membrane-disruptive mechanism of action.

    8.2. Adjuvant Therapy

    Another approach to tackle resistance against vancomycin is through “adjuvant therapy” or “combination therapy”. An adjuvant is an agent that modifies the effect of other agents at comparatively lower concentrations. Small molecules and nanoparticles have been used as adjuvants to potentiate the activity of vancomycin or other glycopeptides against the resistant strains of bacteria. Silver has been known to exhibit antibacterial activity through permeabilization of the bacterial membrane. Induced membrane permeability could sensitize various intrinsically resistant strains of bacteria including Gram-negative pathogens to vancomycin. Collins’ group reported in 2013 that on using silver as an adjuvant, Gram-negative bacteria were sensitized to vancomycin in vitro.(91) They demonstrated that Ag+ potentiated vancomycin against E. coli in a mouse peritonitis model. More recently, polymyxin–tobramycin antimicrobial hybrids, which show potent antibacterial activity (MIC of 2–16 μg mL–1 or 0.7–5.7 μM) against multidrug resistant/extensively drug resistant (MDR/XDR) P. aeruginosa strains have also been demonstrated to act as an adjuvant with various antibiotics against P. aeruginosa.(92) The individual components of the hybrid were conjugated through copper-catalyzed alkyne azide click reaction (CuAAC), a 1,3-dipolar cycloaddition followed by removal of the protecting groups. Vancomycin, which is ineffective against Gram-negative bacteria due to the impermeability of the outer membrane, was potentiated in P. aeruginosa strains due to the synergistic membrane-disruptive activity of the antimicrobial hybrid. The synergistic mechanism was proposed due to fractional inhibitory concentration index (FICI) value of <0.5 in the case of vancomycin. For one of the P. aeruginosa strains, activity of vancomycin improved by 1024-fold (MIC = 0.5 μg mL–1) on using the hybrid as an adjuvant. It has also been reported that Zn (II) mediates vancomycin polymerization and is able to potentiate its activity against vancomycin-resistant bacteria.(93) Glycopeptides have also been used with other antibiotics in combination therapies. In one of these reports, the in vitro activity of teicoplanin in combination with colistin against multidrug-resistant strains of A. baumannii has been proved.(94) The combination of teicoplanin and colistin was found to be bactericidal. FICIs of <0.5 indicated significant in vitro synergy. Using the ETest method, it was observed that the MIC of teicoplanin fell from 256 to ≤2 μg mL–1 at subinhibitory concentrations of colistin. In another report, combination of the lipoglycopeptide, telavancin, with colistin exhibited good activity against Gram-negative bacterial pathogens.(95) The in vitro combination was tested against 66 clinical isolates of Gram-negative pathogens and displayed noticeable synergy with an FICI value of <0.5 against the majority of colistin-susceptible enterobacteria. However, against P. aeruginosa and strains with colistin resistance, only limited effects were seen. Using an Etest assay, it was found that the activity of telavancin was enhanced from >32 to <1 μg mL–1 for 35% of the clinical isolates by relatively low concentrations of colistin (0.25–0.75 μg mL–1). In another study, vancomycin exhibited strong synergistic interactions with nitrofurantoin and trimethoprim against E. coli with vancomycin concentrations as low as 12.5 μg mL–1 in the presence of 3.5 μg mL–1 of nitrofurantoin and 6.25 μg mL–1 in the presence of 0.2 μg mL–1 of trimethoprim.(96)

    8.3. Vancomycin Derivative as Metallo-β-lactamase Inhibitor

    One of the reasons why antibiotics are rendered ineffective in resistant bacteria is inactivating enzymes. New-Delhi-β-lactamase-1 (NDM-1) producing Gram-negative bacteria are resistant to β-lactams including carbapenems. The metallo-β-lactamase enzyme is responsible for the inactivation of β-lactams. In our lab, we have developed a semisynthetic vancomycin derivative, Dipi-van (20, Figure 13A), which is able to penetrate the outer membrane of Gram-negative bacteria and inactivate the metallo-β-lactamase enzyme by depleting zinc ions (Zn2+) from the active site of the enzyme. As a result of this, the derivative at a concentration of 28.7 μg mL–1 was able to resensitize NDM-1 producing Gram-negative pathogens to Meropenem at a concentration of 3.1 μg mL–1 (Figure 13B). The dipicolyl moiety was responsible for depletion of the zinc ions and inhibition of the NDM-1 enzyme activity (Figure 13C). The synergistic effect of the combination was tested against NDM-1 positive K. pneumoniae in a sepsis infection model. The combination reduced the bacterial burden by 3–4 Log CFU g–1 in the liver, lungs, kidneys, and spleen.(97) Thus, vancomycin derivatives like Dipi-van can act as resistance breakers and restore the activity of obsolete drugs against resistant bacteria, including NDM-1 producing bacteria.

    8.4. Other Approaches

    In addition to the aforementioned membrane-active approaches and adjuvant therapy, liposomal formulations of vancomycin have shown promising results against Gram-negative pathogens. It was found that upon loading vancomycin into fusogenic liposomes composed of phospholipid–cholesterol hemisuccinate mixture, MIC values as low as 6 μg mL–1 were obtained against clinical isolates of E. coli and A. baumannii.(98) In another instance, vancomycin was conjugated to gold nanoparticles to yield a polyvalent inhibitor. These Au–vancomycin conjugates were found to exhibit some activity against E. coli with an MIC of 8 μg mL–1.(99)

    9. Treatment of Intracellular Infections, Stationary-Phase Bacteria, and Disruption of Biofilms

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Bacteria are known to establish mature biofilms on medical implants and host tissue, which is an important factor in the persistence of chronic infections. The formation of a biofilm reduces the susceptibility to antimicrobials, thus making treatment difficult. Lipophilic semisynthetic derivatives of vancomycin and other glycopeptides have exhibited good outcomes against stationary-phase and biofilms of S. aureus. Oritavancin induced membrane depolarization, increased membrane permeability, and caused defects in stationary-phase MSSA. Furthermore, oritavancin was successful in sterilizing biofilms of MSSA, MRSA, and VRSA at minimal biofilm eradication concentrations (MBECs) between 0.5 and 8 μg mL–1.(100) Telavancin was also found to be active against Staphylococcus and Enterococcus strains of bacteria embedded in biofilms. MBEC was found to be 0.125–2 μg mL–1. It inhibited biofilm growth at concentrations below its MIC.(101) On the contrary, vancomycin did not demonstrate the same activity (MBEC > 512 μg mL–1) against S. aureus and E. faecalis. In fact, there are reports wherein vancomycin has been shown to promote biofilm formation in Staphylococci at sublethal doses.
    The lipophilic vancomycin conjugates and lipophilic vancomycin–sugar conjugates synthesized in our lab have already been discussed in this Perspective. As a highlight of this report, the optimized lipophilic derivative, 17b, and the lipophilic vancomycin–sugar conjugate 17c were found to disrupt bacterial biofilms of MRSA (>5 log CFU mL–1 reduction of cell viability in preformed biofilms at 5 μM).(83) These results demonstrate a significant activity of oritavancin, telavancin, and membrane-active derivatives of vancomycin against S. aureus in phases of growth that exhibit noninherited resistance to other antimicrobial agents.
    Osteomyelitis and endocarditis are intracellular infections caused by S. aureus. These infections are difficult to eradicate as intracellular localization allows bacteria to be protected from the host immune defenses as well as from the action of many antimicrobials. Oritavancin has been able to show intracellular bactericidal effects (2 log reduction in bacterial load) against S. aureus in a model of THP-1 macrophages.(102) Telavancin, another lipoglycopeptide, has exhibited better cellular pharmacokinetics in mouse macrophages and rat embryonic fibroblasts, as compared to vancomycin.(103) More recently, the intracellular activity of the cationic lipophilic vancomycin derivative, 17a (17, Figure 10) was tested against MRSA in RAW macrophages.(104) This compound exhibited bactericidal activity against intracellular MRSA in a time- and concentration-dependent manner. The intracellular activity was found to be significantly higher than that of vancomycin and linezolid. These findings suggest that lipoglycopeptides are more potent against intracellular infections caused by S. aureus and MRSA in comparison to vancomycin. In addition to these, a novel antibody–antibiotic conjugate (AAC) was able to eliminate intracellular MRSA.(105) The conjugate consisted of an anti-S. aureus antibody (THIOMAB) directed against the wall-techoic acids (anionic glycomers connected to the peptidoglycan of Gram-positive bacteria), covalently linked to a rifalogue (rifamycin derivative) through a cathepsin-cleavable linker. The β-N-acetylglucosamine cell wall techoic acid (β-GlcNAc-WTA) antibody is an attractive candidate for designing an AAC as its antigen is highly abundant in S. aureus during infection and is absent in mammalian cells.(106) The AAC acts like a prodrug which upon opsonizing extracellular S. aureus followed by internalization by cells leads to killing of intracellular S. aureus by active release of the antibiotic. The antibiotic was activated only in the proteolytic environment of the phagolysosome and was superior to vancomycin in the treatment of intracellular MRSA. The THIOMAB AAC was found to be stable in in vivo mice models.(106) Although considerable progress is seen in the approaches to treat such complicated infections, more research still needs to be dedicated toward these aspects.

    10. Other Classes of Molecules That Can Solve the Problem

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Another approach adopted by researchers is to design or identify new antibacterials with different mechanisms of action to fight the battle against drug-resistant bacteria. Compounds with new mechanisms of action can be exploited without any combination or attachment to glycopeptides, thus avoiding cross-resistance. This section covers few of the recent advances in new antibacterial compounds to treat vancomycin-resistant bacteria. Only some of these compounds have been discussed as a detailed literature survey on this topic is beyond the scope of this Perspective.
    Teixobactin is a new antibacterial depsipeptide which is a potential clinical candidate for the treatment of vancomycin-resistant bacteria. It is a cyclic undeca depsipeptide which was isolated by the cultivation of Eleftheria terrae (Aquabacteria) in their natural environment in the presence of certain special growth factors via the use of iChip culturing technology.(107) It was identified as a potential antibiotic against various resistant strains of Gram-positive bacteria in 2015.(107) Teixobactin shows good activity against vancomycin-resistant Enterococcus faecalis and vancomycin-resistant E. faecium (MIC = 0.5 μg mL–1). It was found to be superior to vancomycin in killing late exponential phase populations of S. aureus. It also retained bactericidal activity against VISA.(107) Teixobactin is an example of a novel peptidoglycan inhibitor known to inhibit cell wall biosynthesis and techoic acid biosynthesis by binding to lipid I, lipid II, and lipid III (precursor for wall techoic acid biosynthesis). This suggests that it would be less susceptible to resistance development. Nitrofuranyl benzimidazoles have also exhibited good antimicrobial activity against VRE, with MICs as low as 1 μg mL–1.(108) Moreover, cephalosporins have also shown good activity against vancomycin-resistant strains with MICs as low as <0.5 and 1 μg mL–1 against VRE and VRSA, respectively.(109) Oxadiazoles, another class of antibacterials, have displayed efficacy against VRE (MICs = 1–4 μg mL–1).(110) Another class of molecules that holds promise are antimicrobial peptides (AMPs), which are known to kill bacteria through membrane disruption. In 2004, Omiganan pentahydrochloride (MBI 226), a topical 12-amino-acid cationic peptide, showed decent antibacterial activity against vancomycin-resistant E. faecium (MIC = 2–16 μg mL–1). More recently, other antimicrobial peptides have been reported. For example, a novel bacteriocin from 478 E. faecalis strain, isolated from human feces, has demonstrated high antibacterial activity against several multidrug-resistant enterococci (MDRE) and vancomycin-resistant enterococci (VRE) strains.(111) Among 68 clinical isolates of MDRE and VRE, this bacteriocin was able to inhibit 28 (41.1%). Another antimicrobial peptide that has shown promising results against vancomycin-resistant bacteria is Lugdunin, a novel thiazolidine-containing cyclic peptide antibiotic. It is a nonribosomally synthesized biologically active compound which is produced by nasal Staphylococcus lugdunensis strains, a human-associated bacterium. It shows decent antibacterial activity against E. faecium BK463 (MIC = 3 μg mL–1) and E. faecalis VRE366 (MIC = 12 μg mL–1).(112) Taking inspiration from this peptide, researchers might think of exploring the human microbiota further as a source of novel antibiotics. In another recent report, two short AMPs, WR12 and D-IK8, have been documented to show good activity for treating drug-resistant and intracellular infections caused by S. aureus.(113) The two peptides have shown good antibacterial activity against VISA (MICs 1 and 8 μg mL–1, respectively) and VRSA (MICs ranging from 4 to 8 μg mL–1 and 8–16 μg mL–1, respectively). Moreover, both peptides significantly disrupted the 24 h mature biofilms of S. aureus at a concentration four times the MIC, reducing biofilm mass by 50%. Higher concentrations of vancomycin and linezolid were required (16 × MIC) to reduce the same percentage of biofilm mass. This proves the greater efficacy of the two AMPs in treating biofilms of S. aureus. Some synthetic AMP mimics have exhibited promising activity against vancomycin-resistant bacteria.(114−119) These examples elicit the potential of AMPs and AMP mimics as agents for treating infections caused by vancomycin-resistant bacteria. In addition to this, another class of compounds, caprazamycins and carbacaprazamycins (chemically stable analogues of caprazamycins), have been known to show good antibacterial activity against VRE. Caprazamycins (CPZs) are members of a class of naturally occurring 6′-N-alkyl-5′-β-O-aminoribosylglycyluridine antibiotics and have previously exhibited good antimycobacterial activity. CPZs are inhibitors of the phospho-MurNAc-pentapeptide translocase (MraY), which is responsible for the formation of lipid I during peptidoglycan biosynthesis. In the report, the activity of the optimized carbacaprazamycin was found to be 8 μg mL–1 against E. faecalis SR7914 (VRE) and E. faecium SR7917 (VRE) in comparison to 2 and 1 μg mL–1 with palmitoylzaprazole, which is the less stable congener of caprazamycin.(120) In another report, novel inhibitors of staphyloxanthin virulence factor were designed which showed good activity against VISA infections in vivo.(121) It is considered to be an important virulence factor with antioxidant properties.(122−124) Staphyloxanthin (STX) is distributed in S. aureus and contains numerous conjugated double bonds to resist the reactive oxygen species (ROS) produced by neutrophils and macrophages. Therefore, blocking the STX biosynthetic pathway is an effective therapeutic strategy for complicated S. aureus infections. In the above study, chroman and coumaran derivatives were addressed as novel inhibitors. Two derivatives showed good in vivo activity against VISA Mu50. Various lantibiotics (polycyclic peptide antibiotics containing lanthionine and methyllanthionine residues) and their semisynthetic derivatives have exhibited good antimicrobial activity against vancomycin-resistant strains.(125) Semisynthetic derivatives of nisin were synthesized, which comprised of the N-terminus A/B ring region of the original lantibiotic and lipid amines. The semisynthetic lipopeptides retained lipid II binding and the best derivative showed an MIC of 4 μg mL–1.(126) Another lantibiotic, microbisporicin exhibited MIC of 2 and 0.5–2 μg mL–1 against VISA and VRE (VanA) strains, respectively.(127) Moreover, undecaprenyl pyrophosphate synthase inhibitors were screened for activity against different strains of bacteria. Two 4-oxo-2-thioxo-1,3-thiazolidine based inhibitors displayed MIC of 1–8 and 4 μg mL–1 against VRE, respectively.(128) These compounds are just a few examples of the recent advances in the identification, isolation, and synthesis of novel chemical scaffolds that can be exploited to combat the epidemic of vancomycin resistance. It is expected that in the coming years, more compounds will find their way into the antibacterial armamentarium.

    11. Summary and Outlook

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    WHO had listed vancomycin as a high priority antibiotic in human medicine. Resistance to glycopeptides removes one class of antibiotics from the antibacterial armamentarium for the treatment of serious infections. Numerous initiatives have been taken to overcome this acquired resistance, and this Perspective provides an overview of the chemical strategies that have been used to overcome and treat vancomycin-resistant bacteria. The successful strategies involved modifications to enhance binding affinity to the mutated target peptide, membrane disruption ability, and lipid binding properties. Modifications to afford membrane-disruptive properties into the parent glycopeptide is a promising approach given the low propensity for resistance of these molecules. Molecules with multimodal mechanisms of action may be the way forward because bacteria would then need to devise multiple strategies to develop resistance. Because there is a lack of antibiotics for the treatment of MDR Gram-negative bacteria, the extension of the use of glycopeptides to Gram-negative bacteria would be a welcome strategy. Although this aspect is underexplored, the use of membrane-destabilizing agents in combination with glycopeptides has yielded interesting results. A combination of glycopeptide derivatives with other antibiotics must be thoroughly investigated in order to generate a new therapeutic field, especially for the treatment of Gram-negative pathogens. This would help in employing vancomycin derivatives as inhibitors or resistance breakers in inhibitor/drug combinations. Developing antibiotics or adjuvants that could also overcome the “noninherited” resistance due to intracellular and biofilm-associated infections is an important requirement for the effective treatment of multidrug-resistant infections. The lipophilic semisynthetic glycopeptides have been successful in addressing this problem. This must be kept in mind while designing new strategies. Combination of glycopeptides with known quorum sensing (QS) inhibitors can also be a potential strategy to address the problem of vancomycin resistance. QS refers to bacterial communication, and hence its inhibitors can be advantageous against biofilms of S. aureus whose formation is guided through QS. Further, different classes of compounds other than glycopeptides must be explored thoroughly. Novel chemical scaffolds have an advantage to avoid cross-resistance with glycopeptides.
    Although a lot of work has been done with respect to modification of glycopeptide antibiotics, these compounds are yet to find their way into the clinical pipeline. Challenges in purification and large-scale production of semisynthetic glycopeptides impede the process of drug discovery. Only one semisynthetic glycopeptide, TD-1607, is currently in phase II, but it is not effective against vancomycin-resistant bacteria. Linezolid, which is used as the antibiotic of last resort for the treatment of vancomycin-resistant bacteria, possesses a high propensity of resistance and it is thus imperative to develop new antibiotics and devise new strategies to treat infections caused by multidrug-resistant bacteria. The current clinical pipeline is not sufficient to cope with the increasing cases of resistance in bacteria and the need for new classes of antibiotics remains.

    Global Antimicrobial Surveillance System

    minimum inhibitory concentration

    methicillin-susceptible S. aureus

    vancomycin-resistant Enterococci

    vancomycin-intermediate S. aureus

    vancomycin-resistant S. aureus

    methicillin resistant S. aureus

    heterovancomycin intermediate S. aureus

    vancomycin-susceptible S. aureus

    Food and Drug Administration

    messenger ribonucleic acid

    fmet-tRNA

    N-formylmethionine transfer ribonucleic acid

    community associated pneumonia

    skin and skin structure infections

    complicated skin and skin-structure infections

    (4-chlorobiphenyl) methyl

    EEPS

    electrostatic effector peptide sequence

    membrane insertive element

    extensively drug resistant

    copper-catalyzed alkyne azide click reaction

    fractional inhibitory concentration index

    New-Delhi-β-lactamase-1

    MBEC

    minimal biofilm eradication concentration

    antimicrobial peptide

    multidrug-resistant Enterococci

    caprazamycins

    3. 3
      Tommasi, R.; Brown, D. G.; Walkup, G. K.; Manchester, J. I.; Miller, A. A. ESKAPEing the labyrinth of antibacterial discovery. Nat. Rev. Drug Discovery 2015, 14, 529– 542,  DOI: 10.1038/nrd4572
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      3
      ESKAPEing the labyrinth of antibacterial discovery
      Tommasi, Ruben; Brown, Dean G.; Walkup, Grant K.; Manchester, John I.; Miller, Alita A.
      Nature Reviews Drug Discovery (2015), 14 (8), 529-542CODEN: NRDDAG; ISSN:1474-1776. (Nature Publishing Group)
      A review. Antimicrobial drug resistance is a growing threat to global public health. Multidrug resistance among the 'ESKAPE' organisms - encompassing Enterococcus faecium, Staphylococcus aureus, Klebsiella pneumoniae, Acinetobacter baumannii, Pseudomonas aeruginosa and Enterobacter spp. - is of particular concern because they are responsible for many serious infections in hospitals. Although some promising agents are in the pipeline, there is an urgent need for new antibiotic scaffolds. However, antibacterial researchers have struggled to identify new small mols. with meaningful cellular activity, esp. those effective against multidrug-resistant Gram-neg. pathogens. This difficulty ultimately stems from an incomplete understanding of efflux systems and compd. permeation through bacterial membranes. This Opinion article describes findings from target-based and phenotypic screening efforts carried out at AstraZeneca over the past decade, discusses some of the subsequent chem. challenges and concludes with a description of new approaches comprising a combination of computational modeling and advanced biol. tools which may pave the way towards the discovery of new antibacterial agents.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2MXhtFyks77M&md5=0d3159250e27926ab280c305ea5fb9ef
    4. 4
      Levin, B. R.; Rozen, D. E. Non-inherited antibiotic resistance. Nat. Rev. Microbiol. 2006, 4, 556– 562,  DOI: 10.1038/nrmicro1445
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      4
      Non-inherited antibiotic resistance
      Levin, Bruce R.; Rozen, Daniel E.
      Nature Reviews Microbiology (2006), 4 (7), 556-562CODEN: NRMACK; ISSN:1740-1526. (Nature Publishing Group)
      A review. In addn. to their impressive, well-publicized and well-researched propensity to evolve and acquire genetically detd. mechanisms for resistance to antibiotics, bacteria that are inherently susceptible to these drugs can also be phenotypically refractory to their action. This phenomenon of non-inherited resistance to antibiotics was known since the beginning of the antibiotic era but, relative to inherited resistance, it was given little attention. Here, the authors review the in vitro and in vivo evidence for the different forms of non-inherited resistance and the mechanisms responsible. With the aid of a simple math. model and computer simulations, the authors show how non-inherited resistance could extend the duration of antibiotic treatment, cause treatment failure and promote the generation and ascent of inherited resistance in treated patients.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD28XlvVGlurw%253D&md5=22a627ccfd1443eca63dde7c8e0f3b2a

      Google Scholar
      There is no corresponding record for this reference.
    6. 6
      Nicolaou, K. C.; Boddy, C. N.; Brase, S.; Winssinger, N. Chemistry, biology, and medicine of the glycopeptide antibiotics. Angew. Chem., Int. Ed. 1999, 38, 2096– 2152,  DOI: 10.1002/(SICI)1521-3773(19990802)38:15<2096::AID-ANIE2096>3.0.CO;2-F
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      6
      Chemistry, Biology, and Medicine of the Glycopeptide Antibiotics
      Nicolaou; Boddy; Brase; Winssinger
      Angewandte Chemie (International ed. in English) (1999), 38 (15), 2096-2152 ISSN:.
      The war against infectious bacteria is not over! Although vancomycin and glycopeptide antibiotics have provided a strong last line of defence against many drug-resistant bacteria, their overuse has given rise to more dangerous strains of bacteria. An understanding of the chemistry and biology of these highly complex glycopeptides are destined to play a crucial role in the discovery of new antibiotics.

      7
      Glycopeptide and Lipoglycopeptide Antibiotics
      Kahne, Dan; Leimkuhler, Catherine; Lu, Wei; Walsh, Christopher
      Chemical Reviews (Washington, DC, United States) (2005), 105 (2), 425-448CODEN: CHREAY; ISSN:0009-2665. (American Chemical Society)
      A review on glycopeptide and lipoglycopeptide antibiotics. Structural features, chem. synthesis, mechanism of action, resistance mechanisms and new directions for treating drug resistance are discussed.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2MXmsVaksw%253D%253D&md5=ef3f1a5f07faeacd22c0444d42637fd1
    8. 8
      Butler, M. S.; Hansford, K. A.; Blaskovich, M. A.; Halai, R.; Cooper, M. A. Glycopeptide antibiotics: back to the future. J. Antibiot. 2014, 67, 631– 644,  DOI: 10.1038/ja.2014.111
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      8
      Glycopeptide antibiotics: Back to the future
      Butler, Mark S.; Hansford, Karl A.; Blaskovich, Mark A. T.; Halai, Reena; Cooper, Matthew A.
      Journal of Antibiotics (2014), 67 (9), 631-644CODEN: JANTAJ; ISSN:0021-8820. (Nature Publishing Group)
      A review. Glycopeptide antibiotics have been a key weapon in the fight against bacterial infections for over half a century, with the progenitors, vancomycin (1) and teicoplanin (2), still used extensively. The increased occurrence of resistance and the effectiveness of these 'last resort' treatments for Gram-pos. infections has led to the discovery and clin. development of second generation, semisynthetic lipoglycopeptide derivs. such as telavancin (3), dalbavancin (4) and oritavancin (5), which all possess broader spectra of activity and improved pharmacokinetic properties. Two of these new antibiotics, telavancin (3) and dalbavancin (4), were approved in the past 5 years and the third, oritavancin (5), is awaiting regulatory approval. In this review, the discovery, development and assocd. resistance of vancomycin (1) and teicoplanin (2), and semi-synthetic glycopeptides, telavancin (3), dalbavancin (4) and oritavancin (5), are detailed. The clin. implications of glycopeptide resistance, esp. vancomycin (1), as well as the future prospects for current glycopeptide drugs and the development of new glycopeptides are discussed.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2cXhs1ehsrvK&md5=04a3089be94990f1f3891cd6958ae79a
    9. 9
      Sarkar, P.; Yarlagadda, V.; Ghosh, C.; Haldar, J. A review on cell wall synthesis inhibitors with an emphasis on glycopeptide antibiotics. MedChemComm 2017, 8, 516– 533,  DOI: 10.1039/C6MD00585C
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      9
      A review on cell wall synthesis inhibitors with an emphasis on glycopeptide antibiotics
      Sarkar, Paramita; Yarlagadda, Venkateswarlu; Ghosh, Chandradhish; Haldar, Jayanta
      MedChemComm (2017), 8 (3), 516-533CODEN: MCCEAY; ISSN:2040-2503. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
      Cell wall biosynthesis inhibitors (CBIs) have historically been one of the most effective classes of antibiotics. They are the most extensively used class of antibiotics and their importance is exemplified by the β-lactams and glycopeptide antibiotics. However, this class of antibiotics has not received impunity from resistance development. In the wake of this predicament, this review presents the progress of CBIs, esp. glycopeptide derivs. as antibiotics to confront antibacterial resistance. The various strategies used for the development of CBIs, their clin. status and possible directions in which this field can evolve have also been discussed.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2sXhs1Wmt7w%253D&md5=3ae2916276ca7fc960f137788705c555
    10. 10
      McComas, C. C.; Crowley, B. M.; Boger, D. L. Partitioning the loss in vancomycin binding affinity for D-Ala-D-Lac into lost H-bond and repulsive lone pair contributions. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2003, 125, 9314– 9315,  DOI: 10.1021/ja035901x
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      10
      Partitioning the Loss in Vancomycin Binding Affinity for D-Ala-D-Lac into Lost H-Bond and Repulsive Lone Pair Contributions
      McComas, Casey C.; Crowley, Brendan M.; Boger, Dale L.
      Journal of the American Chemical Society (2003), 125 (31), 9314-9315CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
      The binding affinity of AcNH(CH2)4CH(AcNH)C:ONHCH(CH3)C:OCH2CH(CH3)CO2H (I), which incorporates a methylene (CH2) in place of the key linking amide of Ac2-L-Lys-D-Ala-D-Ala, for vancomycin was compared with that of Ac2-L-Lys-D-Ala-D-Ala and Ac2-L-Lys-D-Ala-D-Lac. The vancomycin affinity for I was approx. 10-fold less than that of Ac2-L-Lys-D-Ala-D-Ala, but 100-fold greater than that of Ac2-L-Lys-D-Ala-D-Lac. This suggests that the reduced binding affinity of Ac2-L-Lys-D-Ala-D-Lac (4.1 kcal/mol) may be attributed to both the loss of a key H-bond (1.5 kcal/mol) and a destabilizing lone pair/lone pair electrostatic interaction introduced with the ester oxygen of Ac2-L-Lys-D-Ala-D-Lac (2.6 kcal/mol) with the latter, not the H-bond, being responsible for the largest share of the 1000-fold redn. These observations have significant ramifications in the reengineering of the vancomycin structure to bind D-Ala-D-Lac and thus overcoming bacterial resistance to vancomycin in its binding to precursor peptidoglycan in cell wall biosynthesis.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD3sXltlCksbs%253D&md5=322f71e8dfe940e24a7b7ec360a417b6

      Uttley, A. H.; Collins, C. H.; Naidoo, J.; George, R. C. Vancomycin-resistant enterococci. Lancet 1988, 331, 57– 58,  DOI: 10.1016/S0140-6736(88)91037-9
      [Crossref], Google Scholar
      There is no corresponding record for this reference.

      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      12
      Avoparcin and virginiamycin as animal growth promoters: a plea for science in decision-making
      Acar, J.; Casewell, M.; Freeman, J.; Friis, C.; Goossens, H.
      Clinical Microbiology and Infection (2000), 6 (9), 477-482CODEN: CMINFM; ISSN:1198-743X. (Blackwell Science Ltd.)
      A review with 51 refs. There is a need to clarify the issue of gene transfer and bacterial population dynamics. Specifically, several issues have to be answered: the extent to which growth promoters select for resistant organisms in animals; the prevalence of resistant enterococci in human populations; their ability to transfer resistance to other organisms; and the question on whether animal enterococci colonize humans.

      13
      Methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus clinical strain with reduced vancomycin susceptibility
      Hiramatsu, K.; Hanaki, H.; Ino, T.; Yabuta, K.; Oguri, T.; Tenover, F. C.
      Journal of Antimicrobial Chemotherapy (1997), 40 (1), 135-136CODEN: JACHDX; ISSN:0305-7453. (Oxford University Press)
      A clin. strain of methicillin-resistant S. aureus strain (Mu50) with reduced susceptibility to vancomycin (MIC = 8 mg/L) is described. The strain did not carry vanA or van B genes, and the exact mechanism of reduced vancomycin susceptibility remains to be detd.

      Infection with vancomycin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus containing the vanA resistance gene

      Tenover, F. C.; Biddle, J. W.; Lancaster, M. V. Increasing Resistance to Vancomycin and Other Glycopeptides in Staphylococcus aureus.       Google Scholar
